references.notes: Apricot kernel oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have moderate penetration (similar to olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Safflower oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have low moderate penetration (lower than olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)

Found that camellia oil can penetrate the hair shaft  at a low-moderate level compared to high penetration oils like coconut. It also found that safflower oil was just as good as coconut oil at preventing damage.
Argan Oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have moderate penetration (similar to olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Study found argan oil was effective at protecting bleached hair from damage, moreso than camellia oil
Found that argan oil could penetrate the hair shaft but not as well as coconut oil. Also found that argan oil increased susceptibility to breakage by making it more vulnerable to water/humidity
Cocoa butter's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have low moderate penetration (lower than olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Sesame seed oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have moderate penetration (similar to olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Avocado oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have moderate penetration (similar to olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Found that avocado oil didn't penetrate the hair shaft as well as argan oil, but did a better job protecting the hair from breakage.
Corn oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have moderate penetration (similar to olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Mustard seed oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have moderate penetration (similar to olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)

Found that camellia oil can penetrate the hair shaft about as well as safflower oil, which is low-moderate compared to high penetration oils like coconut. It also found that camellia oil was just as good as coconut oil at preventing damage.
Rice bran oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair has been well-researched and found to be low. It's likely to coat the hair rather than soak in.
There isn't a lot of research into Castor Oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair, but it's likely given the oil's chemistry
Hemp seed oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have low moderate penetration (lower than olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Coconut oil is well documented to penetrate (soak into) hair
Ucuuba butter is well documented to penetrate (soak into) hair
Grapeseed oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have low moderate penetration (lower than olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)
Jojoba oil is likely to coat the hair rather than soak in, based on its chemistry, so we consider it a light oil

ingredients.name: Lanolin oil
ingredients.description: Lanolin oil is derived from sheep's wool, so it is not vegan. It is a light oil that is likely to coat the hair rather than soak in, based on its chemistry. However, it is likely comedogenic (meaning it can clog pores), so it might not be good for people with oily scalps.

references.notes: Based on this analysis, lanolin seems to have a low percentage of fats that could penetrate the hair shaft
Mineral oil is likely to coat the hair rather than soak in, based on its chemistry

ingredients.name: Petrolatum
ingredients.description: Forms an extremely water repellent barrier on your hair that isn't breathable. Very hard to remove, worse than silicones. Not recommended.

references.notes: Olive Oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair is well documented. It penetrates quite well, but not as well as heavy oils like coconut oil
Flaxseed oil's ability to penetrate (soak into) hair hasn't been well-researched but is it is likely to have low moderate penetration (lower than olive oil, and much less than coconut oil)

ingredients.name: Essential Oil
ingredients.description: Essential oils are not really oils as they are not fatty. They are mainly used for their fragrance and therapeutic properties.
